news.title: Health Care Cost Transparency Could Actually Increase Spending
news.summary: Even when patients are granted access to a health care services price transparency tool, they don’t seem to reduce their spending habits.

news.title: Making health care prices available does not result in lower outpatient spending
news.summary: Offering a health care services price transparency tool to employees at 2 large companies was not associated with lower outpatient spending, according to a study appearing in the May 3 issue of JAMA.

news.title: Access to health-care prices doesn’t lower spending, study finds
news.summary: If people know how much health care services cost, they’ll shop for the best prices and spend less — or so the theory goes.

news.title: Price Transparency Tool Doesn't Cut Health Care Spending
news.summary: (HealthDay News) -- Employee use of a price transparency tool does not cut health care spending, according to a study published in the May 3 issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

news.title: Price Transparency Tool Doesn’t Cut Health Care Spending
news.summary: Advertisement WEDNESDAY, May 4, 2016 (HealthDay News) — Employee use of a price transparency tool does not cut health care spending, according to a study published in the May 3 issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

news.title: Transparent Prices Fail to Lower Health Spending, Study Shows
news.summary: For those who believe that healthcare spending will decrease if patients know the costs and can shop for what they want, findings from a new study in JAMA may be disappointing.
